ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The course is really fun -- I highly recommend it. You get close with your class, you learn a lot of business Japanese (how to speak on the phone, how to speak to your boss, etc) with specific set-phrases. You have daily vocab quizzes, and some reading. Not too much workload but you definitely get to practice speaking.
Well worth taking if you're pretty comfortable with conversational/colloquial Japanese.

Basically the last tier of classes for Japanese at Yale. Hiroe Sensei is a kind, understanding man, and you should take this class if you are looking to improve your Business Japanese and academic Japanese.

This is a fun course, and the seven of us who took it became very close over the course of the semester. Hiroe sensei is a little disorganized but he's also very passionate and reasonable. The course was a combination of keigo practice and discussion of various topics, from history to current affairs. However, grammar is not a focus of this course.

It's hard to summarize this class, because the topics and Japanese people we talk to change each semester, and Hiroe-sensei has students generate a list of things we'd like to discuss. What I can say is that the 9:00 time really defines this class. People often show up late (if they don't completely oversleep), and it's rare that anyone really seems ready to give it their all. Hiroe-sensei is incredibly chill, but I also found him to be a bit disorganized. We received floods of unnecessary emails, there was often ambiguity about what our homework was, and last-minute assignment changes were not uncommon. One incident comes to mind where we received an email at 6 AM on a Monday morning, asking us (with no prior warning) to submit Tuesday's homework by noon that day.
